dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The world turns below us, vast and slow. A RUMBLE. A shadow sweeps over the land. We move with the shadow. We cast the shadow. Landscapes slide by. Reduced by altitude to abstractions: river deltas, forests and flood plains. A raw natural wor No trace of civilization. The shadow glides over mountains and glaciers. Across an ocean and a pale beach. Over lowland plain at the foot of VOLCANIC MOUNTAIN it stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THREE FIGURES walk out of the shadow. They are men - and yet not men. Their skin is snow-white. Their features heavy and classical - as if Rodin’s Thinke had risen from his seat. Their smooth heads are earless a hairless. Their glittering eyes entirely black. Against the stark land their height is impossible to judg They are ENGINEERS. Two of them are cloaked in dark robes of strange design. The third is naked. One of the cloaked Engineers opens a featureless black bo inside lies a cake of dark, sticky material. The naked one lifts the dark cake with ceremonial slownes It hums and buzzes. Foams into iridescent spheres. He rai the seething cake to his mouth like the sacrament. BLACK SCARABS boil out of the dark material. Swarm over h lips. Glittering insects that chitter and bite. Under the swarm his lips melt away. A horrific vision of teeth, black blood, dissolving bone. They are devouring h

dialogues.speaker: FLASH ON
dialogues.text: A fevered glimpse of the microscopic: cells rupture and bleed. Protein chains unfold. A DNA spiral unravels.  The scarabs fill their bellies with genetic material.

dialogues.speaker: THE ENGINEER
dialogues.text: .-+.spreads his arms. Stands cruciform, nearly headless. The scarabs swarm his shoulders, his chest. When they rea his hips, he collapses sideways, toppling majestically li felled tree. Engulfed. The two cloaked Engineers watch impassively. Behind them, a vast black SHIP hangs in the sky. As if blown by a great gust of wind, the scarabs disperse their millions in all directions. Living DNA on the wing. Where the sacrificial victim fell, nothing remains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pristine wilderness. The VOLCANIC MOUNTAIN in the dista A PRIMITIVE WOMAN stands on a height, staring in amazemen far off a great dark ship hovers over the plain. A black scarab lands on the back of her neck. Bites deep. Injecting its cargo of DNA into her blood.

dialogues.speaker: FLASH ON
dialogues.text: A microscopic invasion. Cells pierced and infused. DNA strands twining and mating.

dialogues.speaker: THE WOMAN
dialogues.text: Pupils dilating with shock, breath hissing into her lungs She slaps the back of her neck. Looks at her hand. The sc lies in her palm. As she watches, it crumbles to dust and blows away. FADE TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: ON BLACK
dialogues.text: Drifting motes of light against the dark: a starscape. An EXCAVATOR floats into view: a sturdy vehicle equipped robotic arms. Bright floodlights beat at the darkness. In the cockpit - a bubble of glass - sits a BEAUTIFUL WOMAN. This is DR. JOCELYN WATTS, 32, a precocious scholar of ma disciplines. A scientist accustomed to field work. The cockpit is sweltering: she wears shorts, boots, a T-s - and still her arms and legs gleam with sweat. Watts works the controls. The excavator descends toward a rocky surface. Silt billows up as the excavator approache we're not in space at all, but deep underwater. The excavator’s thrusters are cowled propellers. The “sta are plankton shining in the floodlights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watts steers the excavator to a steeply sloping cliff wal sea-trench yawns below her, its depths lost in darkness.

dialogues.speaker: WATTS
dialogues.text: Moving to survey site B... closing on object four. The large oblong. She watches the screen of a ground-penetrating radar syst A bright signal return: something hidden in the cliff in front of her. Something big.

dialogues.speaker: WATTS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watts carves into the cliff with the excavator’s digger a Silt and boulders fall into the yawning trench below. She brings a water cannon to bear: uses its jet to blast away loose silt and stones. The cliff face collapses: a muddy landslide into the deep Watts backs away from the collapse, thrusters whirring to keep her out of the turbulence. A cloud of silt clears. In her floodlight beams, the OBELISK stands revealed - it outlines worn by the ages. Easily thirty feet tall. Watts stares at the obelisk, stunned. Her voice is husky:

dialogues.speaker: WATTS
dialogues.text: Martin. Here.  A second excavator glides out of the dark. At the controls: PROFESSOR MARTIN HOLLOWAY, 48, visionary genius and archaeologist. Dark-haired and lean, with the rangy build of a frontiersman. He’s dressed in work trous and a T-shirt. Stubbly chin. He plays his floodlights over the obelisk.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: Look at that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watts floats her excavator down the front of the obelisk. Scanning the alien text. Suddenly she stops. Grips the obelisk with her excavator’s arms to anchor herself in pl

dialogues.speaker: WATTS
dialogues.text: You need to see this.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holloway pilots his excavator expertly up to Watts’s. Mat the two vehicles at their aft hatchways. INT. WATTS’S EXCAVATOR Behind Watts, a hatch opens with a splatter of water. Holloway climbs in. Squeezes into her cockpit. A tight fi He’s distracted by her body, pressed so close - but she h eyes only for the inscrutable writing outside the glass.

dialogues.speaker: WATTS
dialogues.text: Same thing again.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: What do you see?

dialogues.speaker: WATTS
dialogues.text: An ephemeris - a star map. (pointing) Radius, inclination, azimuth...more data here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we can get epoch and equinox out of that...

dialogues.speaker: WATTS
dialogues.text: Can we raise this thing?

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) Hundreds of tons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A research vessel at anchor on a turquoise sea. Bright su In the distance, a coastline dotted with villas. The hori is dominated by the VOLCANIC PEAK - the same peak we saw the distance in the prologue. Aboard the research vessel, cranes lift Watts and Hollowa excavators out of the sea and onto the deck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Under an awning, PRINTS of the obelisk’s faces are stretc on the deck - fifteen feet long. Watts and Holloway crawl over the alien text, red markers hand. Parsing, translating, calculating. They're tanned, fit, the wind in their hair. The Mediterranean coast in the distance. It’s an idyllic way work. But they’re utterly absorbed in the task at hand.

dialogues.speaker: AFT DECK
dialogues.text: They're still at it. Lights illuminate the workspace. The obelisk prints are blanketed with markings and annotation Holloway sits at a table. Watts sits on the marked-up pri Both working through calculations on electronic slates. Holloway looks up.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: I have a solution. A single match.

dialogues.speaker: WATTS
dialogues.text: Me too. Checked it twice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You first. Watts holds up her slate: it displays a set of stellar coordinates. A detailed star map. Holloway holds up his o slate: an exact match. They lock eyes in electric excitem

dialogues.speaker: WATTS
dialogues.text: What do we do now?

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: We go there. EXT. WEYLAND’S WHEEL (EARTH ORBIT) A gleaming space station like a five-spoked wheel rotates grandly against the Pacific Ocean a thousand miles below. Black letters on the white metal read: WEYLAND’S WHEEL. A round shuttlecraft approaches the station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A spacecraft no bigger than a private jet. Holloway and Watts sit strapped into acceleration chairs. only two passengers aboard. New to space travel, Watts te her eyes from the spectacle of Earth outside the window. Holloway plays with a pen, batting it from hand to hand i the zero gravity.

dialogues.speaker: WATTS
dialogues.text: What’s first? You do climate, I do genetics?

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: Archaeology first. Let our ancestors tell the tale.

dialogues.speaker: WATTS
dialogues.text: You think he’s serious?

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: Serious enough to send his private shuttle.

dialogues.speaker: WATTS
dialogues.text: Weyland can send his shuttle out for pizza. (delicately) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin. If this meeting goes like the others, maybe we should...

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: It won’t go like the others.

dialogues.speaker: WATTS
dialogues.text: How do you know? Holloway plucks the pen from the air. He points out the window, where the crescent Moon shines like a toothy grin

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: Heaven smiles on our enterprise. EXT. WEYLAND’S WHEEL The shuttle docks with the Wheel’s hub - a perfect fit. INT. WEYLAND’S WHEEL - SPOKE ELEVATOR (ZERO GRAVITY) A gleaming capsule elevator with windows to the stars. Holloway and Watts float weightlessly inside, moving from handhold to handhold. The door closes. Watts grabs Holloway by the collar. Pulls them roughly together. They kiss. Not for the first time. They have a Watts’s hair and clothing float free: she’s a naiad in Holloway’s arms. EXT. WEYLAND’S WHEEL The elevator descends along the spoke to the rim. INT. WEYLAND’S WHEEL - RIM - FOYER A luxurious lobby. Tasteful lighting. Eames-era furniture wood and chrome: the past’s vision of the future. At the rim, the Wheel’s rotation supplies gravity. An elevator door opens. Watts and Holloway step out - Hollow with a sleek metal folio slung over his shoulder. The floor is the outer surface of the Wheel: in both directions it curves upward out of sight. The walls are all windows: on one side, Earth rotates laz On the other, a wheeling field of stars. DAVID, an android, stands waiting for them. He’s cunning built, but no one would mistake him for a real human bein

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Professor Holloway. Dr. Watts. My name is DAVID.

dialogues.speaker: WATTS
dialogues.text: Hello, DAVID.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Mr. Weyland’s eager to meet you. He strides off across the foyer. Watts and Holloway excha a wondering glance and follow.

dialogues.speaker: EXHIBIT HALL
dialogues.text: DAVID leads past models of planets, moons and asteroids. Holographic labels and data swirl around them.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: These are all the planetary bodies on which Weyland Industries has mining claims. The end of the hall is dominated by a huge globe of Mars. Markings indicate widespread surface activity.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And Mars. Weyland’s crown jewel.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: How is that going? The terraforming.

dialogues.speaker: WATTS
dialogues.text: They say you’re getting diminishing returns. It’s not working.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: It’s the greatest engineering project ever attempted. Challenges are inevitable. Mr. Weyland’s a determined man. WEYLAND’S OFFICE PETER WEYLAND sits behind a mahogany desk. He’s a Warren Buffet type: a country sage, horse-sense and hard knocks. might be seventy years old, or a hundred and seventy. Behind him stands DIRECTOR LYDIA VICKERS, a slim woman o in a costly business suit. Shrewd and watchful. Once a gr beauty, she now trades in ruthlessness. DAVID stands against the wall. Watts and Holloway settle into chairs in front of Weyland Holloway holding the metal folio.

dialogues.speaker: WEYLAND
dialogues.text: Professor Holloway. Ms. Watts.

dialogues.speaker: WATTS
dialogues.text: Doctor Watts.

dialogues.speaker: WEYLAND
dialogues.text: Forgive me. Peter Weyland. He notices Watts looking curiously at DAVID. He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: WEYLAND, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ah. DAVID here’s a prototype. Our 80 series. One of a kind for now, but if he performs, he will be legion. (his smile fades) What do you want here? Holloway looks at him, startled.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: We sent you a prospectus that...

dialogues.speaker: WEYLAND
dialogues.text: Assume I know nothing. Holloway swallows. Lays the metal folio on Weyland’s desk

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: I’m an archaeologist. He touches a tiny remote. Holographs appear in the air ov Weyland’s desk: the folio is a three-dimensional imager. Pictures of a younger Holloway in the field: excavating r in Egypt, China, Peru, Greece. HOLLOWAY (CONT’D) In my studies I discovered a pattern I couldn’t explain. Every eleven hundred years, sudden advances in agriculture, tool use, technology. Inventions. Something caused a great leap forward. Every eleven centuries. The pattern holds as far back as our data goes. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOLLOWAY (CONT’D) Tens of thousands of years. I had to understand this. It became the focus of my work. Weyland nods. Holloway glances at Watts and forges on. HOLLOWAY (CONT’D) Dr. Watts was a student of mine. Watts touches her own remote. The holographic display tur to scientific diagrams. Images of a very young and beauti Watts in the laboratory.

dialogues.speaker: WATTS
dialogues.text: I was analyzing historical changes in human DNA. I found the same pattern. Every eleven centuries, a pulse of new information in the genome of the human race. All over the world. Evolution can’t do that. Something was changing us. Changing the DNA of our species.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: Humanity’s been visited. Visited by...beings from somewhere else. Behind Weyland, Vickers can’t suppress a scowl of disdain

dialogues.speaker: VICKERS
dialogues.text: You mean aliens. A beat. The others had forgotten Vickers was there.

dialogues.speaker: WEYLAND
dialogues.text: Lydia Vickers, Director of Operations. Practically my right hand.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: They guided us to civilization. Lifted us up, again and again. I call them the Engineers.

dialogues.speaker: WATTS
dialogues.text: Once you know what you’re looking for, it’s amazing how the evidence falls into place. Photographs flicker through the display: Holloway and Wat in the field, excavating new sites. Intimately close. Their finds: columns of writing on stone tablets in Egypt China, Cambodia, Peru. Patterns of lines, curves, and dot  11.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: This is the writing of the Engineers. We’ve found it on every continent. And last year, we found our Rosetta Stone. The display shows the Engineer obelisk under the sea.

dialogues.speaker: WATTS
dialogues.text: The writing is a formula giving the location of a single star in our sky.

dialogues.speaker: WEYLAND
dialogues.text: Which star?

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: We're keeping that confidential for now. But that’s where we want to go.

dialogues.speaker: WEYLAND
dialogues.text: You want me to pay for an interstellar research expedition!

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: It’s a chance to be part of a revolution in scientific...

dialogues.speaker: WEYLAND
dialogues.text: Don’t sell me, professor. You’ve been turned down by every university and government agency under the sun. Nobody's going to gamble that kind of money on your hunch. Holloway deflates. Watts winces. This is a bloodbath.

dialogues.speaker: WEYLAND, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Nobody but me. (he grins) I’ve read your research.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: That's impossible. Our research is-

dialogues.speaker: WEYLAND
dialogues.text: Quantum encoded on secure servers, yeah. We have an A.I. division, you should know. Doing impressive things. (he leans across the desk) I know which star you’re wishing on. The scientists stare at Weyland.

dialogues.speaker: WATTS
dialogues.text: You're bluffing.  12.

dialogues.speaker: WEYLAND
dialogues.text: Zeta Two Reticuli. He regards their shocked faces with satisfaction.

dialogues.speaker: WEYLAND, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know how I got this rich? I ask myself: what does God spend his time doing? And I go and do that. Watts laughs incredulously. Stifles it. Weyland’s not jok

dialogues.speaker: WEYLAND, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Biotechnology was good to me. Fusion power. Lately doing well with gravity systems. He swivels his chair toward the window. Earth shines outs

dialogues.speaker: WEYLAND, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But what’s the first thing God did?

dialogues.speaker: WATTS
dialogues.text: He made the Heaven and the Earth. Weyland jabs a finger at her like she’s won a carnival pr

dialogues.speaker: WEYLAND
dialogues.text: That's what I’m talking about. You left out my favorite part. The piece about Earth. DAVID.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: For eons, Earth’s climate swung from hothouse to ice age. Explosions of life, then mass extinctions. But twelve thousand years ago the swings stopped. The Holocene Epoch began - a period of anomalous tranquility. The rise of civilization began only then. Holloway and Watts stare at DAVID with new appreciation.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: That’s right.

dialogues.speaker: WATTS
dialogues.text: And that change coincides with a visit by the Engineers. They didn’t just change us. They changed our world.

dialogues.speaker: WEYLAND
dialogues.text: That’s the piece I mean. Engineering Earth. God stuff.  13. He swivels back to his desk. Rummages in a drawer.

dialogues.speaker: WEYLAND, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My people checked your science. They say it’s solid. He pulls a thick contract out. Drops it in front of Hollo

dialogues.speaker: WEYLAND, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I‘ll give you your expedition. Ship and crew, supplies, support. One condition. Holloway picks up the contract with the cautious joy of a double-checking a lottery ticket. His voice is husky:

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: WEYLAND
dialogues.text: You get the discovery. Control of the site. But any technology you find? Anything at all. That’s mine. Holloway reaches out slowly and picks up the contract. Riffles the pages of small-print legalese.

dialogues.speaker: WEYLAND, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You take DAVID with you. My eyes and ears. And Vickers...you’re going too. Vickers stares at Weyland in shock.

dialogues.speaker: WHITE LANDSCAPE
dialogues.text: A glittering formation of white crystals. Diamond on diam The structures grow more complex as the view widens. Leav and branches of crystal. A shimmering field of white jewe A landscape of white crystals, smooth as snow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A black void shot with stars, far from any sun. A sturdy prospecting ship forges through space, travel-wo but built to last. It carries the Weyland Industries logo The name painted on its hull is MAGELLAN.  14.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ship’s nerve center and control room. Six control stations, empty and quiet. Interior lights dimmed to blue The entire forward bulkhead of the Bridge is a window: wa to wall, floor to ceiling. At the window stands the android DAVID. He gazes at the cosmos with an expression of utter sereni After a long moment he turns away. Massive shutters close over the window as he walks off.

dialogues.speaker: CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: DAVID walks the ship’s long central corridor. The ship is silent. The lights dimmed to blue. He is alone.

dialogues.speaker: HYPERSLEEP COMPARTMENT
dialogues.text: A long steel room containing a dozen plexiglass sarcophag six on each side. Sleep freezers. Inside each freezer: th shadowy shape of a human body rimed with frost. DAVID walks through the compartment, surveying the sleepe

dialogues.speaker: WORKROOM
dialogues.text: DAVID sits at a display table, moving intricate technical documents across the surface with waves of his hands. His eyes intent on his work. If he is reading, then he’s reading at a speed no human could match.

dialogues.speaker: WHITE LANDSCAPE
dialogues.text: We pull away from the frosted crystalline horizon, the sm white curves like snowy fields. Form becomes clear. It’s the body of a woman. It’s Watts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watts lies asleep in her underwear in a plexiglass freeze Pale. Frost on her skin. Venus sculpted in ice. There are lines in her elbows and ankles.  15. Shapes move into view beyond her, outside the freezer. FA Pressed to the glass.

dialogues.speaker: HYPERSLEEP COMPARTMENT
dialogues.text: All of the freezers are open and empty, save two. Hollowa lies in one. In the next, Watts. Three men in blue covera crouch beside Watts’s freezer, staring inside. They are DOWNS, 30, a lean fidgety crewman. STILLWELL, 40 sturdy fellow with the geniality of a labrador. And KAMAR 26, whose dark, brooding air belongs to a man twice his a

dialogues.speaker: DOWNS
dialogues.text: Look at that. Kamarov opens the lid of Watt’s freezer. Leans over her. Watts stirs in her sleep, a drowsy angel.

dialogues.speaker: KAMAROV
dialogues.text: She wakes up slow. Watts wakes to find three men looming above her. Disorien she pulls away. Tangles her hands in her IV lines.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Get out of there! Holloway’s voice cracks like a whip. The crewmen jump bac Holloway sits up in the next freezer over. He yanks the I lines out of his arms and legs. Climbs out of the freezer

dialogues.speaker: STILLWELL
dialogues.text: Just looking.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: Give us a moment, will you? The crewmen file out: Stillwell sheepishly, Downs and Kam surly. Holloway goes to Watts. Gently removes the IV line from her ankles while she plucks the ones from her arms.

dialogues.speaker: WATTS
dialogues.text: I’m out of sorts. Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: Never worry. He helps her up.  16.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holloway and Watts sit at a table, both a bit hung over. wear civilian clothes. Warmly dressed, they still look co They nurse mugs of coffee and nibble packaged snack bars. Watts hunches over, shivering.

dialogues.speaker: WATTS
dialogues.text: My head's buzzing.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: You just slept two and a half years. It‘ll pass.

dialogues.speaker: WATTS
dialogues.text: Like you've done this before.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: I’ve read all about it. Two ship’s officers enter the room wearing blue coveralls with rank insignia: GLASSE, 45, a stocky man with thick b hair, and BRICK, 50, a bald man with a bristling mustache They look at Watts and Holloway with little pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: BRICK
dialogues.text: Sleep okay?

dialogues.speaker: WATTS
dialogues.text: Yes, thanks...

dialogues.speaker: GLASSE
dialogues.text: Captain’1l see you now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAPTAIN JANEK, 45, sits at his desk. With his bristling b and powerful build he has a swashbuckling look, like the captain of a whaling ship. Holloway and Watts sit on a steel bench in front of him. He sits scanning his orders: a plastic packet with Weylan Industries logos, cracked open. Watermarked papers inside

dialogues.speaker: JANEK
dialogues.text: Zeta Two Reticuli was surveyed already. A hundred years ago.

dialogues.speaker: WATTS
dialogues.text: By an unmanned probe. Very crude.  17.

dialogues.speaker: JANEK
dialogues.text: No Earthlike planets.

dialogues.speaker: WATTS
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: JANEK
dialogues.text: So what are you looking for?

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: Proof of the Engineers’ existence.

dialogues.speaker: WATTS
dialogues.text: Confirmation of Professor Holloway’s theories would change everything. There'd be science before Holloway and science after. Janek rubs his face wearily with his hands.

dialogues.speaker: JANEK
dialogues.text: Your ticket. I’1l put the ship where you want. Run your scans.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: Captain, your crew’s been up for a week. We could’ve used the time. Why’d you wait to wake us?

dialogues.speaker: JANEK
dialogues.text: Better for discipline. (off their silence) Men ship out as prospectors for one reason: the percentage. Find a gold mine or a habitable planet, and you're set for life. (he laughs bitterly) But this contract says no percentage. No bounty. Just triple pay. The men aren’t happy.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: You unhappy too?

dialogues.speaker: JANEK
dialogues.text: I’m always unhappy. He stands. Presses his palm against a wall panel. A safe opens. He pulls out a massive pistol in a gunbelt. Tosses orders into the safe. Lays the gun atop them and locks it  18. SCIENTISTS’ CABIN Holloway and Watts take possession of their cabin: a simp but spacious room with twin beds and a window to the star They drop duffel bags on the bed. Holloway surveys the arrangement. Frowns. He releases the magnets that lock the beds down. Slides the beds together INT. SCIENTISTS’ WORKROOM - DAY Holloway and Watts set up their workspace - a central dis table and huge display surfaces on the walls. Fascinating documents slide under their fingertips: an Engineer alpha Ancient art. Climate and genetic data. DAVID appears in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: WATTS
dialogues.text: DAVID. I wondered when we’d see you.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I trust your database is in order. I set it up myself.

dialogues.speaker: WATTS
dialogues.text: All’s well, I think. DAVID turns to go. Hesitates in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I should tell you: the time you spent sleeping, I spent studying your research. Holloway and Watts look at the android, his words sinking

dialogues.speaker: WATTS
dialogues.text: You studied our work for two and a half years.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: It’s quite a data set.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: So you've seen everything. Well. What do you think? DAVID glances over the documents displayed around the roo  19.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Your hypothesis is...bold. The audacity of it. Your climate data’s undeniable: the Holocene Epoch was engineered. Dr. Watts, your genetic studies are equally conclusive. Pulses of cultural change are harder to prove, but even there your case is strong. I believe in your “Engineers.”

dialogues.speaker: BREAK ROOM
dialogues.text: A utilitarian sitting room. Steel benches and table bolte the deck. Seated here are two Weyland Industries technici ANDREW CHANCE, 50, a stocky computer engineer with a geni bearing and a bristling salt-and-pepper mustache. MONA RAVEL, 45, a dour, rangy woman with a plain face, he hair pulled severely back. A physicist and chemist. They wear black Weyland Industries jackets. They radiate intelligence and competence. These are pros. DAVID leads Holloway and Watts past the break room. Hollo spots the technicians. Strides in to greet them.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: Weyland Industries! Mr. Chance. Ms. Ravel. You remember Dr. Watts. Watts and the technicians exchange greetings. HOLLOWAY (CONT’D) About the materials I gave you. Some of the technical aspects...

dialogues.speaker: CHANCE
dialogues.text: We'll handle our end of the job.

dialogues.speaker: RAVEL
dialogues.text: If there is a job. Holloway blinks at her. Chance explains, not unkindly:

dialogues.speaker: CHANCE
dialogues.text: We only have a job if you find something.  20.

dialogues.speaker: CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: Holloway and Watts follow the imperturbable DAVID down a steel corridor to Vickers’s cabin door. VICKERS’S SUITE An open-plan cabin like an urban loft apartment. Watts an Holloway follow DAVID inside. Vickers rises to meet them. The walls are industrial steel - but the floors are lushl carpeted, the furniture opulent. A king-sized bed, a maho desk, a dining table. Gleaming machines ensure Vickers never need step outside: private hypersleep freezer, an autokitchen, a medical pod

dialogues.speaker: WATTS
dialogues.text: Is that a Pauling medical pod? There’s only ten of those things on Earth! I guess nine, now.

dialogues.speaker: VICKERS
dialogues.text: I told Mr. Weyland I wouldn’t compromise my standard of living. He accommodated me.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: I know, I had to cut my manifest. This used to be the number four cargo bay.

dialogues.speaker: VICKERS
dialogues.text: What can I do for you, Professor? Holloway gestures with the slate he’s brought with him.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: We’re about to reach the system periphery. I thought you’d want to see the search protocols we -

dialogues.speaker: VICKERS
dialogues.text: No. I was set to be the next CEO of Weyland Industries. Then you came along and sold Mr. Weyland on...this. So here I am. Out of the running. I’ll go where I’m told. But don’t ask me to play along.

dialogues.speaker: WATTS
dialogues.text: But when you get back...  21.

dialogues.speaker: VICKERS
dialogues.text: I'll be five years behind the curve. Out of touch. Over.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: You might make the discovery of the ages. Vickers looks at him as if she’s dealing with a child. HOLLOWAY (CONT’D) You don’t believe in what we’re doing.

dialogues.speaker: VICKERS
dialogues.text: Mr. Weyland believes. That’s enough. She walks them toward the door. Interview’s over.

dialogues.speaker: VICKERS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now we're out of communication, you can tell the crew what we’re doing.

dialogues.speaker: WATTS
dialogues.text: They don’t know? They volunteered.

dialogues.speaker: VICKERS
dialogues.text: They volunteered blind. Classified job, triple pay.

dialogues.speaker: CARGO BAY
dialogues.text: The crew - Brick, Glasse, Stillwell, Downs, and Kamarov - on crates in an improvised lecture hall. Holloway and Wat in front of them. Janek at the back of the room. A hologram shows ancient images of divine visitations. Th crew is visibly spooked.

dialogues.speaker: DOWNS
dialogues.text: Aliens.

dialogues.speaker: GLASSE
dialogues.text: You shitting me? Stillwell is staring at the frightening images: gods and titans towering over mortals.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: I think all our mythologies are race- memories of the Engineers. Horus the Sun God. Prometheus bringing fire from heaven. A pillar of fire, a pillar of smoke. The Engineers are the gods.  22. Kamarov stiffens, smelling blasphemy.

dialogues.speaker: KAMAROV
dialogues.text: The mythology gods maybe. God is God.

dialogues.speaker: STILLWELL
dialogues.text: Kamarov. Let him talk. Stillwell’s staring unhappily at the ancient images: gods towering over mortals, inhuman and terrifying. They turn. STILLWELL (CONT’D) So we’re going to meet these things?

dialogues.speaker: WATTS
dialogues.text: We probably won’t meet anyone. You’d expect a star-traveling race to generate radio or laser signals. Fusion drives and gravity drives have clear signatures. But Zeta Two Reticuli is silent. And the Engineers have gone missing on Earth.

dialogues.speaker: WATTS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: By the pattern, they should’ve come to Earth seventeen centuries ago. And again six centuries ago. But no sign. After twelve thousand years...they stopped coming.

dialogues.speaker: BRICK
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: Exactly. Why?

dialogues.speaker: JANEK
dialogues.text: “My God, my God, why have you forsaken me?” Janek grins at Holloway across the cargo bay.

dialogues.speaker: JANEK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is that the question you’ve come light- years to answer?

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: Only my first question. I have many.  23.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Magellan arrives at the periphery of the system. A distant star like Earth’s Sun, surrounded by orbiting planets: mere sparks at this distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside the vast Bridge window, the star Zeta? Reticuli burns, a cold beacon in the night. Downs, Glasse and Bric sit at consoles. Janek paces in front of the window. Holloway and Watts enter - and gape at the view. Janek gr at their reaction.

dialogues.speaker: JANEK
dialogues.text: Welcome to Zeta Two Reticuli. Edge of the system. Open her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Magellan opens its eyes: two immense telescopes emerg from the ship. Irises open to expose huge lenses. Antennae deploy: unfurling like wings, gleaming and vast. Sifting vacuum for any whisper of information.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside the window, the planets orbiting Zeta? Reticuli a no more than bright stars.

dialogues.speaker: JANEK
dialogues.text: Overlay. A heads-up display appears, overlaid on the glass. The su labeled ZETA? RETICULI. Markers point out the planets and trace the ellipses of their orbits. Like magic, the planets swell into colorful orbs, each labeled: Alpha, Beta, Gamma...

dialogues.speaker: DOWNS
dialogues.text: Seven planets. Two hot rocks, two gas giants, three snowballs. Nothing Earthlike. Watts grins at Holloway, eyes shining.  24.

dialogues.speaker: WATTS
dialogues.text: First humans in the system. Vickers walks onto the Bridge with DAVID.

dialogues.speaker: JANEK
dialogues.text: Director. Good of you to join us.

dialogues.speaker: VICKERS
dialogues.text: What did I miss?

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN JANEK
dialogues.text: Just getting warmed up. (to Holloway) Professor? You know what you want?

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: EMR scan, thirty hertz to three hundred gigahertz. Spectroscopic passes on every planet and major moon. Infrared and albedo scan for hot spots and light sources.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN JANEK
dialogues.text: Man knows what he wants. Run it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twin telescopes spin and zoom. Antennae flex and focus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The planet nearest the sun rushes closer as the mighty telescopes zoom in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Magellan's sensors peel planet Alpha like an onion an put it back together again. A river of data floods the display, bathing the watchers’ faces with light: Chemical compounds, magnetic field line lunar orbits, topographical data. The scan moves on to the next planet, and the next.

dialogues.speaker: GLASSE
dialogues.text: Negative on radio chatter system-wide. Nobody's talking.  25.

dialogues.speaker: BRICK
dialogues.text: Negative for laser and maser. On the H.U.D., the data stream completes the last planet. Begins to illuminate the gas giants’ moons.

dialogues.speaker: GLASSE
dialogues.text: No biological markers. No artificial light. No industry or agriculture. Dead system. Like always.

dialogues.speaker: DOWNS
dialogues.text: Piss-poor, too. Low in heavy elements.

dialogues.speaker: BRICK
dialogues.text: Got a hit! A moon. LV-426. The display centers on Epsilon, a gas giant with many moo Data flickers around one of the larger moons: LV-426.

dialogues.speaker: BRICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Eighty-six percent Earth’s mass. Atmosphere’s nitrogen, methane, sulfates. Faint returns for a bunch of metals.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: Anything else? The sensors complete their pass on the system’s last moon

dialogues.speaker: JANEK
dialogues.text: That is all.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: Take us in.

dialogues.speaker: JANEK
dialogues.text: Downs. You heard the man.

dialogues.speaker: DOWNS
dialogues.text: Aye, Captain. Maneuvering. Eighteen hours to orbit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Magellan retracts its vast antennae and telescopes. The engines fire: the ship rockets toward the gas giant Epsilon and its mysterious moon.  26.

dialogues.speaker: PASSAGEWAY
dialogues.text: Leaving the Bridge, Holloway and Watts find themselves walking aft alongside DAVID.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: DAVID. Enjoy the show?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I don’t know that I “enjoy” things. It was informative.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: It was, it was. (teasing) You know, I’ve seen more convincing humanoid robots. Watts smiles, watching Holloway’s sport. DAVID’s speech n varies from its agreeable tone.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: My design’s not intended to convince. Simulating humanity is a complex task that diverts resources. My designers dispensed with that burden to optimize for intelligence.

dialogues.speaker: WATTS
dialogues.text: Why look like a man at all? Why not be a box on wheels?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Being shaped like you, I can use spaces and equipment designed for you. But I’m not so limited. I hear frequencies you can’t hear. I see wavelengths of light invisible to you. I move faster. Exert greater force. The scientists look at DAVID in wonder.

dialogues.speaker: WATTS
dialogues.text: You see yourself as a superman.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: No. He turns his unearthly eyes on them.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Not a man at all.  27. SCIENTISTS’ CABIN Holloway and Watts lie on their bed in their clothes - he head on his chest.

dialogues.speaker: WATTS
dialogues.text: What if they’re really there? (off his confusion) The Engineers. They could be there. Waiting for us. What then? He laughs.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: Then all my dreams come true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Magellan has arrived. LV-426 is a gray moon shrouded in clouds. Behind it looms father planet Epsilon, a lurid gas giant banded in red an gold, half swallowed in darkness. The Magellan dives into a forced orbit around LV-426: roc firing continually, nose pointed down. Telescopes, sensor and antennae sprout once more from its hull.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone's here. Janek and his crew seated at control stations. Holloway and Watts standing on the foredeck. Vickers and DAVID. Ravel and Chance. LV-426 fills the window: a gray orb of mist. The ground invisible beneath the clouds. Sporadic lightning flickers

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: Start with passive systems. We’re uninvited guests. Let’s be quiet. That thought sends a nervous shiver through the others. J nods at Glass and Brick. They study their instruments.

dialogues.speaker: BRICK
dialogues.text: A lot of electromag, all random. That’s lightning. Going to bugger up our scans.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: Go active. Mapping radar.  28.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Radar emitters extend from their housings like cannons. A THUMP of power as they hammer out a blast of energy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The display paints data on the moonscape as the wavefront comes back: terrain rendered in luminous green.

dialogues.speaker: JANEK
dialogues.text: Well, we just rang the doorbell, if anybody's listening. Kamarov shakes his head fearfully. Crosses himself.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: What do we see?

dialogues.speaker: BRICK
dialogues.text: Icecaps at the poles. Frozen methane. Cold down there. The display fills with light: a wave of terrain data swee across the moon’s surface as the Magellan orbits.

dialogues.speaker: GLASSE
dialogues.text: Terrain data rezzing up. Hey! We got hard spots. Radar-opaque. Bright reflections. That’s metal. A jolt of excitement pounds through everyone on the Bridg

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Magellan sweeps on around the gray moon, radar emitte humming, antennae and telescopes open wide. The gas giant Epsilon fills the sky behind LV-426. As it circles, the Magellan launches SATELLITES. Metal mo hurled into polar orbits around the Moon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty-four “hard spots” shine on the moon’s surface: an irregular array circling LV-426.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: That’s not natural.  29.

dialogues.speaker: MILBURN
dialogues.text: You see stuff like that sometimes. Mineral deposits. Volcanic ejecta.

dialogues.speaker: GLASSE
dialogues.text: Big one there. A new signal appears on the map. Brighter than the others

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: Still quiet?

dialogues.speaker: BRICK
dialogues.text: No comm signals. No signs of life.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: I want to get below the clouds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The prospecting ship descends through buffeting grey clou Telescopes and antennae stowed away. Hull streaming vapor it cuts atmosphere. Lightning flashes and booms around the descending ship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone strapped into chairs - except Janek, who stands gripping a stanchion, his boots planted on the deck. The landing engines roar. Wind screams over the hull. Mis whips across the Bridge window, obscuring any view. Watts reaches out. Squeezes Holloway’s hand. The Magellan breaks through the cloud cover into clear ai Below the ship, a vast and eerie landscape is revealed. W valleys mottled with thin dark ground cover. Barren crags spires of rock. Waterless and wind-swept. Watts gasps. Stares at the grim and foreign country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Magellan thunders over valleys and craggy ridges of r  30.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janek takes the helm. Guides the Magellan down a valley a it were a helicopter. A pilot born.

dialogues.speaker: GLASSE
dialogues.text: Coming up on site seven. They crest a mountain higher than Everest. Before them stretches a dry barren plain. Scattered rocky peaks rise from the desert floor - an alien Monument Vall

dialogues.speaker: DOWNS
dialogues.text: Nothing. Holloway points to a smaller mountain peak. Oddly regular

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: Look there. Janek expertly swings the Magellan sideways. The Magellan circles the mount, nose pointed inward. It revolves below the watchers: flat faces, clean edges - cracked and timework. It glitters like coal. HOLLOWAY (CONT’D) Are we recording? Glasse nods irritably. Of course they’re recording. Vickers stares at the pyramidal peak, nonplussed. Teeteri on the brink of belief. Watts scans the data readouts.

dialogues.speaker: WATTS
dialogues.text: Tungsten, tantalum, aluminum. That could be technology.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: Let’s see the next one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A second oddly regular peak, even more decrepit than the first, sits on the brink of a vast canyon. Landslides hav eaten at its edges. The Magellan purrs over the landscape, dwarfed by the sca Drops between the canyon walls to circle the mount.  31.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holloway and Watts stare at the structure. Beginning to g over the shock. Thinking like scientists again.

dialogues.speaker: WATTS
dialogues.text: Identical, apart from weathering.

dialogues.speaker: MILBURN
dialogues.text: Could be a rock formation. Carbon crystallizes like that. The scientists pay him no mind. They’re past that.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: Let's see the big one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janek pilots by instruments alone. Clouds obscuring the v

dialogues.speaker: BRICK
dialogues.text: Closing on the major site... The ship descends into clear air. A stunning panorama unf before them: craters, hundreds of meters across, connecte trenches. Like a pattern of crop-circles sunk in the rock In the middle of the central crater - a huge angular peak larger than the others. The Magellan circles the site. It awe-inspiring. Cryptic. Huge. Holloway stares in rapture. Glances at Watts: she nods, e shining. She’s with him. The crew’s still skeptical - but starting to wonder. They shake their heads and exchange looks.

dialogues.speaker: BRICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No radio. No heat sources. Cold as the grave.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: Nobody home. Watts looks out at the timeworn peak. Its eroded facets.

dialogues.speaker: WATTS
dialogues.text: I don’t think anybody’s been home for a long time.  32.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the central crater, four canals extend outward like points of the compass. Some connect to smaller craters. One canal peters out, flush with the desert floor. The Magellan lands at the end of this canal - half a kilometer from the central crater.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stare out the window, down the wide straight canal a the pyramidal peak in the distance. Holloway looks around

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: All right. Let’s move. Janek glances at his instruments.

dialogues.speaker: JANEK
dialogues.text: There’s only six hours of daylight left. Maybe you should hold off. Watts looks at him incredulously.

dialogues.speaker: WATTS
dialogues.text: We've got that outside the windows and you want to wait ‘til tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The expedition party emerges from the airlocks - riding C ROVERS, robotic vehicles just smart enough to carry their owners around, or follow along behind them. The rovers’ beds are loaded with gear; the explorers ride running-board seats. All wear space suits. Holloway drives the first rover with Watts beside him. Stillwell, Kamarov, and Downs in back. DAVID drives the second rover with Milburn, Fifield, Chan and Ravel aboard.

dialogues.speaker: WATTS
dialogues.text: The air here will kill you, so keep an eye on your supply and watch your seals. Pathogen tests are clean.  33.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: Move slowly. Stay together. Don’t touch anything. Things may be more fragile than they look - or more dangerous. There might be technologies operating here we don’t understand. The crew of the Magellan exchange uneasy looks. Still uncertain what to think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The trench grows deeper as they follow it toward the cent crater - the pyramidal peak framed ahead of them like a monument on a triumphal avenue. They cross a perpendicular canal. Glancing left and right they see smaller craters with central peaks of their own. They pass through the shadow of a high promontory of ston atop one bank of the canal. We see - and they do not - that the far side of the promontory has a Sphinx-like FACE of monumental size. So eroded that its artificial nature is uncertain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crater floor is a vast enclosed plain. The pyramidal mount looms in the center - colossal in scale. The rovers enter the crater, trailing plumes of dust. The circle the pyramid. On the south face of the pyramid, an IRIS DOOR of many bl stands, easily fifty feet high. Seemingly made of the sam basaltic stone as the pyramid itself. A huge construction The explorers are transfixed in awe. All skepticism banis

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: Tell me that’s a natural formation. (he grins) Undeniable proof of alien civilization. You were here on this day, thirty-one December, year of our Lord 2172. History will remember your names. Watts stares at the iris. Its bottom-most blade is broken lies in rubble at the foot of the door. A dark knife-like aperture leads into the pyramid.  34.

dialogues.speaker: WATTS
dialogues.text: The door’s open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janek and Vickers watch the explorers’ progress in the ma holographic display: their tinny voices echoing over the link. At the sight of the huge iris door in the pyramid, Janek and Vickers stare in blank astonishment.

dialogues.speaker: JANEK
dialogues.text: Son of a bitch. They were right. He turns to stare out the window at the pyramid’s peak. Vickers turns and slips out of the Bridge. Hurries away. VICKERS’S SUITE Vickers strides through her quarters. On the far wall the are two small doors. She opens the first: steps into a luxurious bathroom. Was a pill down with a tumbler of water. Returns to her cabin and opens the second small door.

dialogues.speaker: SECRET ROOM
dialogues.text: A chamber walled with steel panels. A deep hum of ventila and power: there’s a lot of technology here. She turns to a console beside the door. Flips a row of switches. The hum deepens. Hidden mechanisms stir to life

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On foot, explorers press inside - Holloway and Watts in t lead. Their flashlights cut into the gloom. The robotic rovers follow them: their six-wheeled chassis with independent suspension trundling over the rubble barrier, sure-footed as goats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dark and cavernous. Weak daylight slants in.  35. The explorers press into the darkness on foot - the cargo rovers’ headlights flashing on. They move through a dark cathedral space, empty and bare. DAVID looks around in fascination, his eyes raking the wa

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: Jocelyn. Here. His voice trembles with urgency. He shines light on the r Symbols engraved on the dark surface. Dots, lines and arc HOLLOWAY (CONT’D) The writing of the Engineers. Conclusive connection. DAVID stands beside them. Stares at the alien writing.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Congratulations, Professor Holloway. Watts passes her light over the writing, recording it. Th move on into the dark. DAVID lingers. Reading.

dialogues.speaker: PYRAMID
dialogues.text: The interior is a labyrinth. Corridors big as railway tun intersecting and diverging. The explorers wend their way deeper. Several carry map un whose holographic displays render three-dimensional maps expand as they explore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holloway leads the explorers deeper into the complex. The motors of the cargo rovers whine and growl. DAVID trails the others, eyes raking the blank walls as i sees something there. He reaches out. Passes his hand thr the air as if grasping a cobweb. A STRANGE RUMBLING NOISE sounds down the corridor, freezi them. Holloway sweeps his light that way. The sound comes again: a DEMONIC VOICE speaking some unearthly language. Watts looks at Holloway - but his eyes are focused on the dark ahead. He moves forward. A beat. The others follow.  36. An APPARITION appears before them. A PALE, LUMINOUS GIANT fifteen feet tall, with hollow eyes and a grotesque snout strides toward them. Speaks in a sonorous voice. Pandemonium. Watts backpedals involuntarily. Seeing Holloway stand his ground, she reaches out to him in a panic.

dialogues.speaker: WATTS
dialogues.text: Martin. Martin! But Holloway doesn’t budge. Stares at the Apparition in fascination. Everyone else scatters - except DAVID, who stands stock-still by the wall. Watts watches as the Apparition walks right up to Hollowa Disappears with a sizzle of static as Holloway experience the creature passing through him. Silence. Watts returns to Holloway’s side. Stillwell and Downs are huddled on the deck. Milburn and Fifield have fallen back down the passageway.

dialogues.speaker: FIFIELD
dialogues.text: Christ. Christ!

dialogues.speaker: RAVEL
dialogues.text: It wasn’t real.

dialogues.speaker: MILBURN
dialogues.text: We all saw it. Unseen by the others, DAVID reaches out and repeats his gesture in the air. A rumbling sound down the corridor, as before. Moments la the Apparition appears round the corner again. They stand their ground: the ghostly giant strides toward them, exac as before, and disappears with a crackle.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: Recording?

dialogues.speaker: FIFIELD
dialogues.text: No more. I’m out.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: Fifield. Get a grip.

dialogues.speaker: FIFIELD
dialogues.text: I’m a prospector. You find a load of bauxite, I’m your man. But not this.  37.

dialogues.speaker: MILBURN
dialogues.text: I should go with him. Buddy system.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: (disgusted) Fine. He hauls a heavy rolling case out of the cargo rover. HOLLOWAY (CONT’D) You can deploy the drones. Drop them in the first or second nexus on your way back.

dialogues.speaker: FIFIELD
dialogues.text: Give us a rover.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: And half our gear? It’s no more than a mile. You can walk it. Sulking, Milburn takes the rolling case. The remaining explorers watch Fifield and Milburn backtrack into the da

dialogues.speaker: CORE CHAMBER DOOR
dialogues.text: Holloway and Watts lead their party up to a massive door, sealed tight. In design and scale, undeniably important. Holloway glances at his map.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: This should lead to the core of the pyramid.

dialogues.speaker: WATTS
dialogues.text: Jack it open? Or cut through?

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: Let’s do as little damage as we can. Ravel waves a sensor over the wall.

dialogues.speaker: RAVEL
dialogues.text: There’s power. Current flowing in the wall. Chance begins to inspect the frame of the door.

dialogues.speaker: CHANCE
dialogues.text: Maybe we can hack it. Has to be a mechanism...  38. DAVID looks as if they fail to see something obvious. He points at a spot on the wall beside the massive slab.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Pull up a rover. I want to get up there. INT. MAGELLAN —- BRIDGE - DAY Janek stands at the window, looking down the long canal a the distant pyramid. The ship’s powerful imaging systems stream data: stereosc feeds from the explorers’ flashlights; a map that grows a they explore. The maze under the pyramid drawn in light. A globe of LV-426 blooms with terrain and weather data as satellites feed the ship information. Vickers appears at Janek’s side.

dialogues.speaker: JANEK
dialogues.text: Director. Taking an interest?

dialogues.speaker: VICKERS
dialogues.text: It’s my operation, isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A junction where multiple passageways converge. Milburn and Fifield trudge into the space, trundling the probe cases behind them. Tunnels lead away in all directi

dialogues.speaker: FIFIELD
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: MILBURN
dialogues.text: Grand Central Station. They open the case. CAMERA PROBES tumble out: spheres the size of softballs, studded with lenses and sensors. Tiny lights come on as the probes awaken. They roll off, dispersing to investigate every passageway. Bumbling into walls and pillars, reversing. Exploring by random walk.

dialogues.speaker: FIFIELD
dialogues.text: Let’s check the feed. Gimme the map.

dialogues.speaker: MILBURN
dialogues.text: You had the map unit.  39.

dialogues.speaker: FIFIELD
dialogues.text: You don’t have the map? They stare at each other.

dialogues.speaker: MILBURN
dialogues.text: Are you serious? He trudges back the way they came, in disgust.

dialogues.speaker: MILBURN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come on.

dialogues.speaker: CORE CHAMBER DOOR
dialogues.text: DAVID stands on top of one of the cargo rovers. He’s cut hole in the wall beside the door, high up: he works with probes in the mechanisms inside.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Looks like a three-state switch. A deep BOOM, echoing inside the ancient walls. Nothing mo

dialogues.speaker: DAVID, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: One moment... He moves a control. BOOM. The immense door begins to rise

dialogues.speaker: PYRAMID
dialogues.text: The vast central chamber of the pyramid. An immense space Holloway walks in, his flashlight searching. Watts hurrie after. The others follow, rovers tagging along. A colossal structure stands in the center of the chamber, convoluted and strange. A mechanism. Chasms yawn in the f all around it, their depths lost in darkness. The explorers enter, rovers in train. They lift their eye hundreds of feet above them they see the pyramid’s apex f within. A SHAFT OF DIFFUSE LIGHT penetrates the pyramid somewhere near the peak.

dialogues.speaker: RAVEL
dialogues.text: This is something, now.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes, it is.  40. The android’s awareness is keyed to a high pitch. He seem read meaning in the inscrutable structures all around the Holloway hauls a drone case out of the rover. Two dozen spherical drones tumble out, wake up, and roll off into t dark. They are nimble, hopping curbs and skirting chasms. Watts looks at her atmosphere sensor. Astonished.

dialogues.speaker: WATTS
dialogues.text: Martin. This air’s breathable. The core chamber brightens as the sun outside moves into alignment. The shaft of light perfectly centered. A vast SIGH as if the pyramid itself is breathing. A fat drop of water falls on Watts’s glove. She looks up surprise. Another falls on her visor. And then it’s raini inside the pyramid. Water trickles into the chasms, inundating the mossy grow that cling to the walls. Holloway looks at Watts with a little boy’s grin.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: Miracles and wonders! The shaft of light moves on. The core chamber dims slight The rainfall stops as suddenly as it started. The explorers follow the main path around the periphery o the chamber, past a gallery of mysterious machines. There are marvels in the shadows. Cells in the dark appar open on startling deposits of color: translucent alabaste flutes. Honeycombs of pure gold. Matrices of crystal. Watts waves a scanning instrument as she walks.

dialogues.speaker: WATTS
dialogues.text: Intense field readings. Huge power sources here.

dialogues.speaker: PYRAMID
dialogues.text: They arrive at a wide opening in the floor. A strange ram curves downward - its floor segmented and saw-toothed. A bafflement: it’s not a staircase. Not an escalator. No moving parts. No rails or tracks.  41.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: Space below us. A big space. As they stand looking, a probe bumbles up to the opening goes bounding down the ramp. Watts laughs.

dialogues.speaker: WATTS
dialogues.text: How does this work? She begins to descend on foot. Holloway behind her. Stillwell, Downs, and Kamarov grudgingly follow. But DAVID looks away across the cavernous chamber - fixat on the central crystal. He beckons Ravel and Chance to fo him, and walks away. Ravel and Chance look at each other in astonishment. Uncertainly, they follow DAVID.

dialogues.speaker: LOWER PASSAGE
dialogues.text: Holloway, Watts, and the crewmen reach the bottom of the ramp, breathing hard. A cargo rover trundles down after t They look back up. The ramp above them is empty.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: Ravel. Chance. Where’ve you gone? DAVID! Where are you? (to Watts, indignantly) They didn’t come down! But Watts is staring through an archway. Transfixed.

dialogues.speaker: WATTS
dialogues.text: Look. She walks in. Holloway follows.

dialogues.speaker: CONTROL CONCOURSE
dialogues.text: A passageway punctuated by alcoves as big as band-shells. In each alcove stands a biomechanical apparatus - shaped the same dark material as the pyramid itself. Each appara implies by its design that a giant is meant to fit inside Holloway and Watts walk the concourse, playing their ligh over the dark machinery. Their footsteps echo.  42.

dialogues.speaker: WATTS
dialogues.text: Do you see, the size of them? Like that ghost we saw...

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: It wasn’t a ghost. Where are the others? I don’t want to go back up. Watts fiddles with her suit’s comm controls. Listening.

dialogues.speaker: WATTS
dialogues.text: They switched to channel three. I hear them talking. They’re okay.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: We should stay together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milburn and Fifield are lost. They bumble through the dar

dialogues.speaker: MILBURN
dialogues.text: This is not the same place.

dialogues.speaker: FIFIELD
dialogues.text: It is! That is the same freaky thing we saw before. He points at a detail of the architecture.

dialogues.speaker: MILBURN
dialogues.text: No it’s not! The other one was more... sort of...fuck it. (taps his comm) Milburn to Magellan. Come in. Static.

dialogues.speaker: INTERSECTION
dialogues.text: Holloway and Watts round a corner and stop in their track Kamarov, Stillwell, and Downs almost run into them. The scientists stand frozen. In front of them lies a dead giant. An ENGINEER. If he were standing, he would be fifteen feet tall. He is roughly human in shape. Barrel-chested. Withered to bones. There are bulky protrusions fused with his flesh: to say whether they are equipment or parts of his body.  43. His head, lolling to one side, is severed from his body. His eyes seem to be covered by goggles; but if so then th goggles are fused with his skull. An elephantine probosci severed now, once connected to a protrusion on his hip. The giant lies frozen in a convulsion of agony. His jaw gaping in a silent scream. His corpse is marred by hideou wounds: slashes that cut through bone. The explorers move closer. Speechless.

dialogues.speaker: KAMAROV
dialogues.text: God in Heaven.

dialogues.speaker: WATTS
dialogues.text: Martin. Martin.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: I know. Look. He lifts his light. Beyond the dead giant, a vision of He A dozen DEAD ENGINEERS lie heaped against a sealed door. Twisted in postures of torment, murdered in the attempt t escape. All bear horrific wounds. Scene of an ancient massacre.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janek and Vickers stare dumbstruck at a 3-D view of the d giants captured by the explorers’ cameras.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The explorers circle the decapitated giant, hushed with a Holloway steps close.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: “There were giants in the earth in those days...and when the sons of God came in unto the daughters of men, they bare children to them, who became mighty men." Genesis six four. Lays a gloved hand reverently on the giant’s ribs.

dialogues.speaker: DOWNS
dialogues.text: (panicky) You said don’t touch anything! You said don’t touch anything!

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: Peace.

dialogues.speaker: CHANCE
dialogues.text: The size of them!

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: In all the old mythologies, the visitors from the sky were giants. Watts joins Holloway beside the dead Engineer. Touches th corpse in her own turn. It’s hard as stone: ossified. She traces the ancient, terrible wounds.

dialogues.speaker: WATTS
dialogues.text: They were killed. All of them. Downs stands staring at the dead giant, as shaken as Kama

dialogues.speaker: DOWNS
dialogues.text: We shouldn’t be here.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: Come on. The dead can’t hurt you. (adjusts his communicator) DAVID. Chance. Ravel. I’ve got something here. Static.

dialogues.speaker: WATTS
dialogues.text: Communications are going to hell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the Magellan's satellites hurtles along, high abov the moon’s atmosphere. It passes over the terminator line between the night side and day side. Through the clouds below, a lightning-laced storm front r across LV-426 like a wave. INT. MAGELLAN —- BRIDGE - DUSK Rising winds pluck at the ground cover outside the window Janek turns from the view to look at the holographic glob

dialogues.speaker: JANEK
dialogues.text: All hands. Back to the ship. We got a mean storm front rolling in. I repeat. All hands...  45. INT. DARK CITY —- CATACOMBS - INTERSECTION Standing beside the dead giant, Watts and Holloway look a each other as the signal comes in.

dialogues.speaker: JANEK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (staticky) front rolling...back to the ship.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: (into comm) We've found something here! I’m not walking away for bad weather.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janek shouts into his communicator.

dialogues.speaker: JANEK
dialogues.text: Holloway! I got two-hundred-kilometer winds with airborne silica and enough static to fry your suits. Get your asses back here! Now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holloway races their cargo rover away from the pyramid, wheels kicking up dust. Watts rides in back, securing a bulky payload under a tar the cargo deck. Stillwell, Downs, and Kamarov clinging miserably beside her. Watts looks back: A massive storm front chases them. A tidal wave of dust s through with lightning. Gale-force winds tear at the grou Lightning lashes the pyramid and the crater wall. Reaching the Magellan, they see the other rover already i the airlock lift. DAVID, Ravel, and Chance aboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holloway roars into the lift at speed, the rover skidding almost into the opposite wall. Watts leaps down. The storm wall catches up to them. Screaming winds rip through the lift. Dust fills the air. Visibility plunges toward zero.

dialogues.speaker: WATTS
dialogues.text: Help me unload!  46. She pulls at the tarp. It tears halfway free - and fills wind, snapping taut with such violence that Watts is hurl out into the storm.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE GALE
dialogues.text: Watts tumbles helplessly: a leaf in the wind. CRASHES int metal stanchion. Clings, the wind knocked out of her. Ear ringing. Nothing but static in her headset.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE LIFT
dialogues.text: Holloway stares in shock at the place where Watts vanishe

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: Jocelyn! With inhuman reflexes DAVID reacts. Grabs a tether. Latch it to his suit. Locks it to an anchor point on the wall. Dives into the storm. A ballet nearly too fast to follow.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE GALE
dialogues.text: DAVID lets the wind take him. Skids across the ground, controlling his trajectory. He hits the stanchion where W is lodged with a CLANG as if he were made of iron. Watts stares at him in mute astonishment. He locks her suit to his. Activates the tether unit’s win It whirs, reeling them in through the hurricane.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE LIFT
dialogues.text: Holloway and the other crewmen haul Watts and DAVID back inside. Holloway and Watts embrace fiercely as the lift r toward the safety of the ship. The crewmen bundle the rover’s tarp-wrapped cargo into a sealed dumbwaiter that rises independently into the ship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The explorers strip off space suits. Watts pulls her helmet off. Catches DAVID’s eye across th airlock. Mouths a silent Thank you. He gives her the bare nod and vanishes into the ship.  47. The explorers exchange looks. A mood of exuberance and wo prevails now that they’re safe home.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: Day one. Smiles of wonder as what they’ve seen comes home.

dialogues.speaker: DOWNS
dialogues.text: Got to hand it to you, professor. You were right. Both of you.

dialogues.speaker: CHANCE
dialogues.text: What’s in the tarp? What’d you bring back? The explorers from Watts and Holloway’s party exchange lo and burst into laughter.

dialogues.speaker: WATTS
dialogues.text: You don’t want to know.

dialogues.speaker: STILLWELL
dialogues.text: Shit. We’re two helmets short. He points. The lockers labeled MILBURN and FIFIELD stand closed. The helmet racks empty. The laughter cuts off.

dialogues.speaker: KAMAROV
dialogues.text: They didn’t come in! They stare at each other, listening to the wind wail outs

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janek speaks urgently into the communicator.

dialogues.speaker: JANEK
dialogues.text: Between the wind speeds and the static electricity, there’s no safe way to get to you. You’re going to have to hunker down until it passes. How are your provisions?

dialogues.speaker: FIFIELD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We got air <static>. Water and food tabs <static> suits.

dialogues.speaker: JANEK
dialogues.text: Honey sacks?  48.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifield and Milburn stand miserably in a murky passageway Fifield hitches up his space suit’s crotch uncomfortably.

dialogues.speaker: FIFIELD
dialogues.text: Yeah, we’re piped.

dialogues.speaker: MILBURN
dialogues.text: I hate these fucking things. INT. MAGELLAN —- BRIDGE - DUSK

dialogues.speaker: FIFIELD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We hate these fucking <static>, Captain.

dialogues.speaker: JANEK
dialogues.text: Maybe next time you’1l mind your maps. Keep your heads down. We’1ll come get you in the morning. A burst of static answers him: Fifield’s voice scrambled the storm. Unintelligible.

dialogues.speaker: JANEK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Magellan out.

dialogues.speaker: MESS ROOM
dialogues.text: All hands present excepting the two missing men. Janek pl his squeeze box, its archaic music filling the air. Tired exuberant, the men sway and dance mockingly. Holloway has a champagne bottle open in each hand. He fil steel cups left and right.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: My friends. What we do here marks the greatest achievement of our species. Contact with another civilization. Humanity came of age today, on this moon. You were there. (raises his glass) To history. They raise cups and drink. Even the crew moved by the mom But Janek smiles crookedly and toasts again.  49.

dialogues.speaker: JANEK
dialogues.text: To Milburn and Fifield. The first human beings to freak out, get lost, and sleep in their suits in the ruins of an alien civilization.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A vast dark maze. Milburn and Fifield grope their way thr the dark with flashlights. The storm howls outside.

dialogues.speaker: MILBURN
dialogues.text: What are you looking for?

dialogues.speaker: FIFIELD
dialogues.text: (groping along the wall) Someplace things can’t come at us.

dialogues.speaker: MILBURN
dialogues.text: What’s gonna come at us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAVID stands beside Vickers at her holography terminal. H lays his hand on over a signal plate - and the terminal lights up with a three-dimensional image. The core chamber of the pyramid, from DAVID’s point of vi It’s apparent that DAVID’s eyes see more than human eyes He seems to see heat and electromagnetic energy as well a visible light; calibrated readouts are overlaid on the sc The structures in the pyramid are surrounded by complicat patterns of energy. This is incomprehensible technology.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: The core of the pyramid. You see. Vickers goes rigid, looking at it: avarice in her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: VICKERS
dialogues.text: We're going to protocol two.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I understand.

dialogues.speaker: LABORATORY
dialogues.text: A high-tech science facility behind glass. Watts and Holloway, in lab gloves and smocks, open the dumbwaiter:  50. An ENGINEER'S HEAD rises into view, ghoulish and elephant Vapor rises from it. A readout blinks: STERILIZED. They lift it onto the steel table. It takes both of them. They pass scanners over the skull. Images accumulate and rotate on the laboratory displays. X-ray and ultrasound. Holloway leans close to study an X-ray image. He almost s to see a ghostly second face...

dialogues.speaker: WATTS
dialogues.text: Martin. Look. She traces the head with an ultrasound probe: under the vibrations a seam opens up around the edge of the face. She gets a fingertip into the seam. Works with a probe. P away the long-dead Engineer's mask. It comes free. The visage revealed is human, except for its giant scale. White-skinned. Earless. Hairless. Withered but beautiful Greek statue. Eyes closed. An expression of suffering on face. Watts drops the ultrasound probe in shock.

dialogues.speaker: WATTS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They look like us.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: We look like them. Genesis 1:27. “And God created man in his own image. In his own image created He him." Vickers and DAVID stand outside the lab window, staring i the god’s head. Vickers looks shaken. DAVID, fascinated. Watts covers her nose in revulsion. A horrible stench: Th Engineer head begins to disintegrate in front of them. Fl oozing, skin peeling. Accelerated decay. HOLLOWAY (CONT’D) It’s breaking down.

dialogues.speaker: WATTS
dialogues.text: Formaldehyde! Urgently they ransack cabinets and storage rooms. Watts f a clear plastic drum and dumps its contents. Holloway dra five-gallon jugs of preservative out of a cabinet. DAVID watches through the window, almost amused.  51.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Mortal after all. They lift the rotting head into the drum, retching. Finge skidding in putrefaction. They pour formaldehyde over it. As soon as the head is immersed they rush to strip off their reeking gloves and smocks, scrubbing their hands. The god’s head sits in its murky vat, shedding skin and t like chunks of white flesh. The noble face disintegrating Watts and Holloway stare at it, breathing hard from their work. Vickers flicks on the intercom from outside the win

dialogues.speaker: VICKERS
dialogues.text: Your cadaver’s interesting. But I’m more interested in the machinery in the pyramid. The core chamber. What do you think it does? Watts stares at Vickers incredulously.

dialogues.speaker: WATTS
dialogues.text: How could anyone know...

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: I know what it does. Silence. Holloway looks at Vickers wearily, as if he’s se this conversation coming. He glances at Watts. HOLLOWAY (CONT’D) Think. What we’ve seen. What we know. Watts rises to the challenge. Thinking on her feet.

dialogues.speaker: WATTS
dialogues.text: Twenty-four pyramids scattered around the moon’s equator. Massive power supplies. Vents in the walls. Atmosphere changes. Breeder tanks... (she’s got it) The pyramids are terraforming machines. Holloway grins, exuberant. His theory playing out perfect He doesn’t see Vickers stiffen. Her hands curling into fi

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: That's why Earth’s ancient cultures built pyramids: in imitation of the gods. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Twelve thousand years ago, beings from the sky set pyramids on the Earth and transformed the world. That’s what they were doing here - before their civilization failed. Watts stares at the head in its tank. The severed neck.

dialogues.speaker: WATTS
dialogues.text: It didn’t fail. It was wiped out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milburn and Fifield have bunked down in a new chamber: th slouch against a wall. Milburn sweeps the room with his headlamp. Stoops to lift something into the light.

dialogues.speaker: MILBURN
dialogues.text: Look at this! A CENTIPEDE, three feet long and thick as man’s thumb. It hard shell is gray. It has a hammer-head like a shark.

dialogues.speaker: FIFIELD
dialogues.text: Jesus! Put it down! He leaps back, wild-eyed. Milburn laughs at him. Lets the eyeless centipede wind it segmented body around his space-suited arm. In the flat face, a white vertical slit appears. Changes quickly to a horizontal position; opens enough to suggest mouth. Milburn doesn’t notice this development.

dialogues.speaker: MILBURN
dialogues.text: Relax. Your suit’s bug-proof. Hell, it’s bulletproof. The centipede spirals around his arm, glittering, its bod moving in fluid waves. The blind head quests between his fingers. Milburn loses his nerve as the thing’s mouth suddenly gapes wide as a shark’s.

dialogues.speaker: MILBURN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That’s enough. He tries to pull it off. The centipede locks its segments together and digs in wit its body. It might as well be made of iron.  53.

dialogues.speaker: MILBURN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (panicking) Get it off! It’s crushing me! Fifield pulls out a utility knife. Cuts into the centiped body behind its head. A gout of greed ACID spills over Milburn’s glove. Smoke r as the acid quickly burns a hole through the material. Milburn’s shout of astonishment turns to a wail of agony.

dialogues.speaker: MILBURN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: AHH! Help me! Christ! The centipede snakes into the smoking hole in the glove. Crawls upward into Milburn’s suit - toward his head. INT. MAGELLAN —- LABORATORY - NIGHT Holloway stands studying the data displays: cross-section the Engineer's skull. Watts scrutinizes the head itself, her nose an inch from plastic tank. Not a pretty sight. As she watches, a current in the formaldehyde peels away gossamer eyelid. The revealed eye is black as obsidian, iridescent like opal. A jewel. Fascinated, Watts pulls out a plastic case. Opens it to reveal a high-tech control unit with a screen. She pops o a plastic capsule: removes a tiny SEED PROBE, smaller tha grain of rice. Drops it into the vat. Under her guidance, the seed probe swims to the severed n Burrows into the medulla oblongata toward the brain. ON A SCREEN: In the probe’s POV the medulla looks like a tunnel. The probe climbs along neural channels. Another screen shows the probe’s progress through the sku Glasse enters. Stands beside Holloway to watch Watts at w

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: You won’t get anything. Tissue’s too degraded. Hmm. Brain chamber’s massive, even proportionately.

dialogues.speaker: WATTS
dialogues.text: Neural paths are still conductive.  54. The seed probe reaches the optic nerve of the exposed eye and its POV fills with a vision of glory: a beautiful wom face surrounded by a mystical nimbus of light. An angel. Glasse and Holloway gasp. The woman in the blurry vision Watts - as seen by the dead Engineer's eye.

dialogues.speaker: GLASSE
dialogues.text: Incredible. The image dissolves into noise. Error messages flicker ac the display. Watts sighs.

dialogues.speaker: WATTS
dialogues.text: Formaldehyde’s killing the tissue. Holloway stares at Watts, awe on his face.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLOWAY
dialogues.text: Did you record that?

dialogues.speaker: WATTS
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: AT A LAB TABLE
dialogues.text: Watts dissects one of the Engineer’s eyes - working underwater in a shallow tub of preservative. Glasse looks avidly, an unabashed fan. Watts wears a pair of magnifying goggles on her forehead the lenses lowering and rising at need. She bisects the apple-sized eyeball carefully and extract the hard lens from behind the cornea. Holds the lens up t her eye. It is opalescent, almost luminous.

dialogues.speaker: WATTS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The lens is where the phase shift happens. The uncorrected view through the lens is blurry.

dialogues.speaker: WATTS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Glasse. I want to look through these lenses. Can you seal them and do the optical correction? Glasse reaches out and plucks the magnifying goggles from Watts’s forehead. He grins.

dialogues.speaker: GLASSE
dialogues.text: Got an idea about that.  55.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milburn writhes on the ground, heels drumming frantically against the deck. Excruciating screams. Fifield kneels over him, helplessly pulling at the tail o the centipede - which has all but vanished into Milburn’s suit. A trickle of scarlet from the hole. Fifield is delirious with horror. He clutches at the centipede in vain. It slips through his gloves. Milburn claws at Fifield, wild-eyed.

dialogues.speaker: MILBURN
dialogues.text: Cut off my arm. Cut off my - He convulses. Spits blood. The head of the centipede emer between his teeth. He seizes. Choking and dying.

dialogues.speaker: FIFIELD
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ! He leaps up. Backs away. Runs into the dark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
